abstract.p: The periodic vehicle routing problem (PVRP) is an extension of the vehicle routing problem (VRP). Because it extends the single delivery period to a T-day period (T > 1), PVRP has strong theoretical and practical significance. Since PVRP is an embedded VRP, it is more complex and difficult compared with the general VRP. In this paper, the bee colony algorithm is used to solve the PVRP. To improve the performance of this algorithm, multidimensional heuristic information and a local optimization based on a scanning strategy are used. At the end of this paper, the algorithm is tested by some well-known examples. The results show that the proposed improved bee colony algorithm is a powerful tool for solving the PVRP. It also shows that these two kinds of strategies can significantly improve the performance of the algorithm.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The vehicle routing problem (VRP) has important theoretical and practical significance in the field of logistics research. The traditional VRP can be used to optimize routing in a single delivery period (e.g. one day). However, many practical problems require distribution in more than a single delivery period (e.g. within a period of one week or one month); that is, to conduct multiple deliveries in one cycle. Examples can be found in retail distribution, garbage collection and plant parts procurement. The periodic vehicle routing problem (PVRP) is a development of the VRP. The PVRP extends the single delivery period to T periods (T > 1), in which a single customer may need more than one service in T periods.

There have been many studies related to PVRP in the literature. Beltrami and Bodin1 first used PVRP to assign hoist compactor trucks in municipal waste collection. Chao et al.2 proposed a heuristic algorithm for PVRP. The algorithm consisted of two phases: the initial solution construction phase and a solution improvement phase. Baptista et al.3 studied the waste-paper box recycling problem; in this PVRP, the frequency of visits to containers was considered as a decision variable in their model. The PVRP was then solved with an improved heuristic algorithm: Drummond et al.4 solved the PVRP with a parallel heuristic algorithm that consisted of a parallel genetic algorithm and local search algorithm; Francis and Smilowitz5 proposed an improved heuristic algorithm to solve the PVRP, in which customer service frequency was regarded as a decision variable. Pourghaderi et al.6 created a simple and effective line construction algorithm through an embedded improving procedure to solve the PVRP. Matos and Oliveira7 improved the quality of ant colony algorithm optimization by a pheromone update strategy to solve the PVRP. Yu and Yang8 presented an ant colony optimization based on two improved strategies to solve the PVRP with time windows. Information about other heuristics for PVRP can be found in further studies.9–14

The PVRP needs to optimize each delivery period for the customer combination, and the path selection optimization for each delivery period. Therefore, the PVRP is an embedded VRP problem and is more complex than a single VRP. Researchers have proved that the simulated biological heuristic method is very suitable for solving large-scale combinatorial optimization problems. The artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm simulates the process of bees looking for nectar, through the exchange, transformation and collaboration between the different roles to achieve swarm intelligence. In the ABC algorithm, each alternative solution is called a food source and the process of gathering nectar (the food source) is the process of searching for the optimal solution. In the algorithm, the profitability (the amount of nectar) can embody the value of the food source. The profitability, in the judgment of the algorithm, directly determines the optimal direction. The goal of the entire system is the optimal solution of the profitability function.

The ABC algorithm was inspired by the behavior of real bees looking for nectar, creating a simulated evolutionary algorithm based on swarm intelligence. The bee colony algorithm has achieved success in solving a series of complex combinational optimization problems. Seely15 proposed the bee colony self-organization simulation model. In the model, although bees within the colony only complete a single task, through the bees' dance swing, smell, etc., i.e. a variety of means of information exchange, the entire colony can collaborate to complete work such as building the hive and harvesting pollen. Karaboga16 successfully applied the bee colony algorithm to the numerical optimization of function and brought out a more systematic ABC algorithm. The ABC algorithm was then further applied to solve restrictive numerical optimization by Karaboga and Basturk,17 and achieved a better test result.

As a novel heuristic algorithm, the ABC algorithm is a simple, robust and population-based stochastic optimization algorithm that has achieved success in solving a series of complex combinational optimization problems. Özbakir et al.18 applied an ABC algorithm to solve generalized assignment problems with an ejection chain neighborhood mechanism. Koudil et al.19 attempted to use an ABC algorithm to solve a integrated partitioning/scheduling problem in codesign. Other research into ABC algorithms can be found in Karaboga.16 These successful applications motivated us to apply an ABC algorithm to generate and optimize a variety of potential routes. Therefore, in this paper the ABC algorithm is also used to solve the PVRP problem.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we construct the mathematical model for PVRP. In Section 3, the ABC algorithm and some improvement strategies are presented. In Section 4, some computational results are discussed; and the conclusions are provided in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. Periodic vehicle routing problem
sec.p:
The PVRP is a case in which the demands and the service frequency of customers are given. In each distribution, the vehicle starts from a distribution center, services the customers in the same period, finally returning to the distribution center. The most obvious difference between PVRP and VRP is that all the customers are served in the same day in VRP while not all the customers are served in the same day in PVRP. sec.title: 3. The improved artificial bee colony (IABC) algorithm
3.1. The basic principles
sec.p: The bee colony algorithm simulates the process of bees looking for nectar, through the exchange, transformation and collaboration between different roles to achieve swarm intelligence. In the ABC algorithm, each alternative solution is called the food source and the process of looking for nectar (food source) is the process of searching for the optimal solution. In the algorithm, the profitability (nectar amount) can embody the value of the food source. The profitability is the judgment of the algorithm, directly determining the optimal direction. The goal of the entire system is the optimal solution of the profitability function. Bees may have one of three roles: employed bee, onlooker and scout. Scouts correspond to the food sources that are to be collected. Food source is the target of the leaders. Scouts share information with other bees to recruit more employed bees to collect the food source. The degree of information shared is proportional to the profitability of the food source. The scouts randomly search for new food sources near the hive and enhance the ability to jump out of the local minima of the algorithm. The followers obtain profitability information from the leaders, and then choose a food source according to the roulette method. This plays an important role in the process of convergence of the algorithm. The variety of bees in the bee colony algorithm exchange information in the dance area, and the leaders complete the recruitment of the food source through swing. Dance intensity is proportional to the profitability of the corresponding food source. All scouts are waiting in the dance area and select the appropriate food source according to the observed dance information.

sec.title: 3.2. Generation of solutions
sec.p: The PVRP is different from the VRP. The solution of PVRP is constituted by the combination of multiple delivery lines during the period T. As each customer may be accessed many times in the distribution cycle, and the specific delivery date is uncertain, using the pheromone representation of the traditional single-cycle VRP it is difficult to distinguish the heuristic information of customers at different delivery dates.

This paper presents a multidimensional heuristic information matrix to represent the profitability situation between customers at each delivery date. The multidimensional heuristic information matrix can be viewed as more one-dimensional matrices, that is, to maintain a separate heuristic information matrix for each distribution date. In other words, each customer has heuristic information on each distribution date and a different distribution date with different heuristic information. The proposed algorithm is to distinguish the best distribution combination between different delivery dates. Heuristic information in a multidimensional matrix is shown in Figure 2. For example, the first matrix describes the heuristic information for the first day, and the dth matrix describes the heuristic information for the dth day. When optimizing the routes for the first day, the heuristic information in the first matrix is used. When optimizing the routes for the dth day, the heuristic information in the dth matrix is used.

As the number of bees continually being a leader gets larger, the more followers attracted by the leader there will be. The bee colony will tend to one of several fixed food sources, and the algorithm easily falls into the local optimum. To overcome premature convergence of this algorithm, the number of bees continually being a leader should be controlled. Limit is used to describe the maximum number of bees continually being a leader. If the variation of the length of the path traversed is less than 1% in limit time, the leader is forced to abandon its path and it is permitted to be a scout in the next cycle. Thus, the parameter limit can enhance the global search ability of the algorithm. In addition, to retain the path with the highest profitability, the longest path is then replaced with the shortest path at the end of each cycle.

The mutation operation, referring to the genetic algorithm, alters each child at a predefined probability. The operators can help the IABC to reach further solutions in the search space. Thus, the mutation operation can be used to further the search space. The mutation operation of the path is as follows: to all the paths, pick node j randomly and the same probability (j≠ 1), exchange the jth and (j – 1)th node and leave the rest unchanged; if j = 1, then exchange the first and the last node. sec.title: 3.4. Local optimization
sec.p: The bee colony algorithm is a stochastic search algorithm. It is easy to fall into the local optimum, resulting in a solution that cannot be optimal or near optimal. Therefore, most of the bee colony algorithms use a local search algorithm to jump out of local minima. The local optimization described in this paper consists of two phases: one phase is local optimization in the path; the other phase is local optimization between paths. Local optimization in the path is to optimize the customer nodes’ sorting of all the paths in the current program based on the 2-opt method. This method has been elaborated upon in many papers.20,21 The following will mainly discuss local optimization.

If there is a crossover point between two paths in one optimization program, the program can usually be improved. Therefore, elimination of the crossover point22–24 is an efficient method of conducting local optimization. Most researchers search for the crossover point with an enumeration method (that is, compare all the paths) and this greatly reduces the efficiency of the algorithm. Especially in solving large-scale VRP, this algorithm takes a lot of computing time, thereby reducing the practicality of the algorithm. The local optimization of this paper is also based on the idea of reducing the crossover phenomenon in the program. In order to improve the efficiency of the local optimization algorithm, a scanning method is introduced in this paper to search the crossover phenomenon quickly and optimize it. The specific steps are as follows:

sec.title: Step 1: initialization
sec.p: The scanning strategy proposed in this paper is based on the angle between the customer point and distribution center,8,25 therefore it is necessary to make sure of the locations of the customer point and distribution center. First, establish a coordinate system and choose the coordinates of the distribution center as the origin, then draw a line to the customer point in the two-dimensional space according to the coordinates. PVRP has its own characteristics; it does not have the condition to be locally optimized between the paths on two days, that is, only the distribution paths on the same delivery date can be locally optimized. Using the distribution paths for the first day from Figure 1 as an example, the spatial distribution of the distribution center and customer point can be as shown in Figure 4. Then initialize each customer; and this operation includes the perspective of each customer and their respective paths. For example, the angle of customer C4 is 115.3° and the picked path is 1, stated as (115.3°, 1).

sec.title: Step 2: search for the potential crossover path based on the scanning strategy
sec.p: Sort all the customer points in accordance with their angle values, and record the path number, as shown in Figure 5. Then, starting from the customer with the smallest angle value, the number of the path can be changed (i.e. from customer C3 to C2, the path number changes from 1 to 3) by scanning all the paths belonging to each customer. However, if the changed number is the scanned one (i.e. customer C2 to C4, the path number changes from 3 to 1), this is the phenomenon of ‘fallback’. If the customer points in one path are continuous and do not show the fallback phenomenon, this indicates that the path does not cross with the other paths (i.e. path 2); if there are fallback phenomena, there is the possibility of an existing intersection. Then check if the path that has the possibility of an existing intersection meets the tabu list: if they meet, then go to step 3 to determine whether there is a crossover point between two paths; if not, continue to scan. If scanning to the final customer point still does not show fallback phenomenon, go to step 6.

sec.title: Step 3: judge whether there is an intersection between two paths
sec.p: Compare all the sections between two paths in the proper sequence to detect whether there is an intersection. The steps to determine whether two paths have an intersection are as follows.

Assume that there are two paths ab and cd, in which the coordinates of the two endpoints of the path ab are (x1, y1) and (x2, y2); the coordinates of the two endpoints of the path cd are (v1, w1) and (v2, w2).

sec.title: 2. If x1 = x2 or v1 = v2
sec.p: If x1 = x2 and v1 = v2 then the two paths do not intersect.

If x1 = x2 and v1≠v2, make z = x1 into the linear equation of path cd to obtain the vertical axis Z. If Z is between w1 and w2 the two paths intersect; otherwise the two paths do not intersect. The case x1≠x2 and v1 = v2 is similar.

In the judgment, if the two paths do intersect then go to step 4, otherwise continue to traverse. If there is no intersection between the two paths after traversing, then go to step 5 and add these two paths to the tabu list to avoid repeating the judgment process.

sec.title: Step 4: the local optimization of intersecting paths
sec.p: Traverse all possible combinations of the four endpoints of the two intersecting paths, searching for the combination that can shorten the delivery distance to the greatest degree. If the combination is superior to the current program, then use this combination to replace the current program and optimize these two paths with the 2-opt method which was also used by Yu et al.20, then go to step 6; otherwise, go to step 5 and add these two paths into the tabu list.

sec.title: Step 5: update the tabu list
sec.p: In order to avoid judgment duplication of the scanned invalid cross paths and cross-section, this paper establishes two tabu lists: the cross paths tabu list and the cross-section tabu list. The tabu length of the tabu object is λ, that is, the tabu paths and sections shall not be selected to judge whether they intersect during the continuous λ time scanning process.

sec.title: Step 6: terminate judgments
sec.p: If there is no intersection between all the paths or the process reaches the preset maximum number of iterations, then the local optimization based on the scanning strategy is over, otherwise go to step 2.

sec.title: 4. Casestudy
sec.p: In order to test the performance of the improved bee colony algorithm in this paper, nine PVRP benchmark instances from the literature2,26 were used. The customer scale of the nine classic instances is from 50 to 100, the number of vehicles is from one to six and the cycle length is from two to ten days. Specific information about the instances is shown in Table 2. The traditional bee colony algorithm randomly selects a food source to generate the initial solution, but this could lead to the initial position of the food sources being selected by the leaders too often. Because the leaders tend to choose the points closer to the current position in the initial search, making the intensive food sources locally converge too quickly at the beginning easily leads to premature convergence.27 The ‘interval distribution method’ principle is used in this paper to determine the initial position of the food source. That is, sorting the customer in accordance with the angle between the customer point and axis, and then placing the bees’ space evenly, makes the food sources as evenly distributed as possible.

Visual studio.NET 2003: C++was used to achieve the improved bee colony algorithm proposed in this paper. The operating environment was a Pentium IV 2.93 GHz processor with 3 GB and the Windows platform. A large number of experiments led to the parameters being set to p = 1, s = 6, A = 100, Limit = 5, ρ = 0.99 and λ = 10. In order to test the performance of the algorithm, the calculation results of the ABC algorithm were compared with the heuristic proposed by Chao et al.2 (noted as CGW) and the tabu search method proposed by Cordeau et al.26 (noted as CGL). To evaluate the performance of the three algorithms, the ratios from the values of the three algorithms compared to the best-known values was used. The ratios of the nine PVRP benchmark instances optimized are shown in Figure 6 and Table 3.

caption.p: Computational results using IABC algorithm and well-known published results.
Computational results using an IABC algorithm and the best-known published results.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 6, the results of the proposed algorithm for some instances are better than the known optimal solution. The results of instances 3 and 9 from our algorithm were better than the best-known results; the results of instances 2, 4, 6 and 7 reached the best-known solutions; the proposed algorithm did not acquire the best-known values of instances 5, 8 and 10. Compared with the CGW and CGL algorithms, the IABC algorithm can achieve better optimization results in relatively simple problems (instances 3 and 9). But for the relatively complex problems (instances 5, 8 and 10), the optimization results of the IABC algorithm is similar to those of the CGW algorithm and inferior to those of the CGL algorithm. Overall, the IABC algorithm proposed in this paper is a very competitive algorithm for solving PVRP.

The IABC algorithm proposed in this paper mainly consists of two improvement strategies: a multidimensional profitability update strategy and the local optimization method based on scanning. In order to specifically analyse the effect of the two strategies, the following test was constructed. To test the effect of multidimensional profitability, a single-dimensional profit (ABC+SP) matrix and a multi-dimensional profit matrix (ABC+MP) were designed. In order to test the effect of the scanning strategy, the local optimization of the traverse search method with multidimensional heuristic information optimization (ABC + MPB) was used. During local optimization, this method goes through all the paths rather than scanning the potential cross-path. The lengths and the computation times from the ABC + SP, ABC + MP and ABC + MPB methods were compared to those from the IABC algorithm under the same conditions. The ratio of the lengths and times can be found in Figure 7 and Table 4.

caption.p: Comparison of the performance among four ABC algorithms.
Comparison of the performance between four ABC algorithms.

sec.p: As is shown in Figure 7, the optimal performance of the ABC + MPB and IABC algorithms is sharply superior to that of the ABC + SP and ABC + MP algorithms. It shows that the local optimization operation can effectively make the algorithm jump out of the local optimal and improve the quality of optimization. The ABC + SP and ABC + MP algorithms’ computation time is much less than that of the ABC + MPB and IABC algorithms and it shows that local optimization operation is a relatively time-consuming calculation. The performance of the ABC + MP algorithm is superior to the ABC + SP algorithm, and better than the ABC + SP algorithm by 9.5%. It shows that using the single-dimensional heuristic information bee colony algorithm for solving the PVRP problem is very difficult. Compared with the ABC + MPB and IABC algorithms, using the ABC + MP algorithm with multidimensional heuristic information to optimize, performance is still relatively poor. After comparing the performance of the ABC + MPB and IABC algorithms, it can be found that, for all of the instances, the results of the ABC + MPB algorithm are better than or equal to the IABC algorithm. Due to the searching process of the ABC + MPB algorithm, all of the paths were tried, and the optimization results of the algorithm were naturally superior to the IABC algorithm. However, the solving time of the ABC + MPB algorithm is actually almost twice that of the IABC algorithm, and the same time the performance of the ABC + MPB algorithm is almost equal to the IABC algorithm, about 0.09% better than the IABC algorithm. Comprehensively comparing the optimal quality and computation time, the IABC algorithm is an efficient solution for the PVRP problem.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, we have proposed an improved bee colony algorithm for solving the PVRP problem. There is more than one delivery period for the PVRP and the customer service combination is uncertain for each period, therefore PVRP has a greater complexity than the standard VRP. In order to determine the final customer service combination of each delivery period, this paper proposes a multidimensional profit matrix to represent the probability of the customer in different periods. As the bee colony algorithm is easy to fall into a local optimum, this paper proposes a scanning-based optimization algorithm to make the algorithm jump out the local optimum. Finally, the performance of the algorithm is validated by a number of classic instances. The results show that the algorithm has a good performance in solving the PVRP problem.
